title: 105_s2091
content:
The "Emergency Medical Services Efficiency Act of 1998" is also known as the Act. It includes provisions for Medicare coverage of certain ambulance services. The Act, also known as the "Emergency Medical Services Efficiency Act of 1998," amends Section 1861(s)(7) of the Social Security Act to ensure ambulance services are treated as medical services, even if the ultimate diagnosis shows they were not necessary, as long as the request is made after a sudden onset of a severe medical condition. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to items and services provided on or after the date of enactment of this Act, defining serious impairment to bodily functions or serious dysfunction of any bodily organ. TITLE II--STATE EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES AGENCY PARTICIPATION IN CERTAIN FEDERAL PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. TELEMEDICINE AND DISTANCE LEARNING SERVICES IN RURAL AREAS. Amends Section 2333(c)(1) to include State emergency medical services agencies as 'entities'. Effective upon enactment of this Act.

SEC. 202. INFORMATICS, TELEMEDICINE, AND EDUCATION DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. SEC. 202. INFORMATICS, TELEMEDICINE, AND EDUCATION DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. Amends Section 4207(c) of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 to allow State emergency medical services agencies to participate in the consortium. Effective upon enactment of this Act. SEC. 301 defines emergency ambulance services as resources used to deliver medical care under emergency conditions, including services by licensed emergency medical personnel. The Federal Commission for Emergency Ambulance Services is established with 21 members appointed by various leaders and organizations, including the American Academy of Pediatrics. The Federal Commission for Emergency Ambulance Services includes members appointed by various organizations such as the American Academy of Pediatrics, American Ambulance Association, American College of Emergency Physicians, and American College of Surgeons. The Federal Commission for Emergency Ambulance Services includes members appointed by organizations like the American Hospital Association, American Society for Testing and Material, Associated Public Safety Communications Officials International, and Association of Air Medical Services. The Federal Commission for Emergency Ambulance Services includes members appointed by various organizations, such as the Emergency Nurses Association, International Association of Fire Chiefs, and International Association of Fire Fighters. The Federal Commission for Emergency Ambulance Services appoints members from different organizations, including Indian tribes, the National Association of Emergency Medical Services Physicians, and the National Association of State Emergency Medical Services Directors. Emergency Medical Services Directors are appointed by the President from various organizations, including the National Association of Emergency Medical Technicians, the National Rural Health Association, and the National Volunteer Fire Council. In appointing Emergency Medical Services Directors, geographical and urban/rural representation is important. Appointing officials must select members who represent different areas of the United States, with 11 members each from rural and urban areas. The Commission members must be appointed by January 1, 1999, for a 4-year term. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The initial meeting must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Commission shall hold its first meeting at the call of the Chairperson. A majority of members constitute a quorum, but fewer can hold hearings. The Commission will select a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson from its members. The Commission is tasked with studying emergency ambulance services and related federal rules, developing recommendations for improvement, and submitting annual reports to the President and Congress. They have the power to hold meetings, select leadership, and conduct hearings. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. They also have authority over personnel matters. Members of the Commission do not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits. They are allowed travel expenses and per diem while away from their homes. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The employment of an executive director by the Commission requires confirmation. The Chairperson can set their compensation and that of other personnel without following certain provisions of the United States Code. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without additional compensation, maintaining their civil service status and privileges. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates that do not exceed the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay prescribed for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Secretaries of Labor, Commerce, and Health and Human Services will equally provide necessary funds to the Commission. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. A study and report on consolidating federal authority over emergency medical services will be conducted. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study and make recommendations on transferring emergency medical services functions to a single Federal agency, excluding functions of the Department of Defense and Federal health care programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to the President and Congress within one year of the enactment of the Act, detailing the results of the study on transferring emergency medical services functions to a single Federal agency, along with any legislative recommendations deemed necessary.
